articles.title: Residents pick up the pieces as wild weather weakens
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: Cyclone Zelia made landfall at Port Hedland, in north-west Western Australia as a category four cyclone. There were no deaths or injuries in Western Australia. The downgraded weather system is still dumping significant rain on parts of the Pilbara region, exacerbating flooding.

articles.title: Air evacuations underway as ex-Tropical Cyclone Zelia triggers dangerous flooding
articles.author: Rachel Ward
articles.summary: Rising flood waters triggered by heavy rainfall in a cyclone will pose a danger in northwestern Australia for days. West Australian Premier Roger Cook urged residents to stay alert. The DeGrey River at the Great Northern Highway is expected to reach major flood level on Saturday afternoon. At least 63 people have been evacuated from the remote community of Warralong as floodwaters rise.

articles.title: Geauga Park District joins in on Great Backyard Bird Count
articles.author: Frank Mecham
articles.summary: The Geauga Park District is participating in the Global Bird Count from Feb. 14-16 at the West Woods Nature Center, 9465 Kinsman Road in Russell Township. The event is run by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology and is called the Great Backyard Bird Count.

articles.title: Meanwhile in Australia…
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: Meanwhile in Australia, Nature is Amazing is celebrating Valentine's Day on February 15, 2025.    pic.twitter.com/2xBPCbnAEs   in Amazon's timeline, which also includes Australia's version of the same date.

articles.title: WA, Queensland eye clean-ups as wild weather weakens
articles.summary: Cyclone Zelia made landfall at Port Hedland, northwest Western Australia as a category four cyclone. It has weakened to a tropical low as it tracks southwards. There were no reported deaths or injuries in Western Australia. The downgraded weather system is still dumping significant rain on parts of the Pilbara region, exacerbating flooding. Roads have flooded, cutting off critical connections for supply deliveries. Emergency warnings remain for people in the Pil Barbara towns of Warralong and Marble Bar. Flood warnings are also in place in flood-devastated areas of Queensland.

articles.title: No immediate relief in sight from climate crisis
articles.author: Ananda Banerjee
articles.summary: January this year was the warmest since weather record-keeping began in 1901. 18 out of the past 19 months saw the global average surface air temperature exceed 1.5°C above the pre-industrial levels. The US has started the process of exiting UNFCCC for the second time under the leadership of Donald Trump.

articles.title: Was 1.5C a Climate Propaganda Whoopsie?
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Mike Hulme is a professor of human geography at the University of Cambridge. He argues that putting a deadline on climate action was the wrong way to frame it. January was a record 1.75 degrees C warmer than the preindustrial average, but he doesn't think the world is at the edge of disaster.

articles.title: January 2025 Breaks Global Heat Record Despite La Niña, Marking 18th Month Above 1.5°C Threshold
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: January 2025 was the warmest January ever recorded. It was 1.75°C above pre-industrial levels, surpassing January 2024, which occurred during an El Niño event. January 2025 is the 18th month in the last 19 months where the global-average surface air temperature exceeded 1.5°C. The Arctic saw joint-lowest sea ice extent on record for January. Five named storms formed globally during the month, below the average of seven.

articles.title: Earth is already shooting through the 1.5°C global warming limit, two major studies show
articles.author: Andrew King
articles.summary: Earth is crossing the threshold of 1.5°C of global warming, according to two major global studies. Under the Paris Agreement on climate change, humanity is supposed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and keep planetary heating to no more than 1°C above the pre-industrial average. Last year was the hottest on record.

articles.title: Heat withers Africa's cacao, scientists warn of climate threat to chocolate
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest year on record in West Africa, especially in Ivory Coast and Ghana. The region accounts for 70 percent of the world's cacao production. Farmers in the region have struggled with heat, disease and unusual rainfall in recent years. That has caused an explosion in the price of cocoa, produced from the beans of the cacao tree.

articles.title: B.C. Climate News: Are B.C. risks properly assessed and mitigated?
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says humans are the main drivers of climate change. It warns the window to limit warming to 1.5 C above pre-industrial times is closing. The Earth is now about 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The past 10 years are the 10 warmest on record.

articles.title: (Hello Africa) Namibian farmers tune into radio for climate resilience amid changing weather patterns
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Climate change has brought unpredictable weather patterns to many parts of Namibia, leaving farmers struggling to produce enough yields. Radio broadcasts for weather forecasts supplement farmers' traditional knowledge. Agatus Timo, an 87-year-old farmer with over 50 years of farming experience, has faced numerous challenges in recent years, including droughts, floods and pests.

articles.title: March, April temperatures in Sri Lanka expected to be higher than previous years
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Temperatures in Sri Lanka during March and April 2025 may be higher than in previous years. Malith Fernando, a meteorologist from the country's meteorological department, said that the likelihood of heatwaves will increase in the coming months. Global warming is significantly impacting weather patterns.

articles.title: Sea ice hits historic low as temperatures soar near North Pole
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Sea ice in the Arctic and Antarctic is at a record low. The recent record-low sea ice levels are likely caused by a mix of warm air, warm ocean waters and winds. In early February, temperatures near the North Pole were about 20C higher than normal, causing ice to melt in areas like Svalbard.

articles.title: Andhra Pradesh Sees Sharp Weather Contrasts
articles.author: K.M.P. PATNAIK
articles.summary: Temperatures in ASR district dropped by 7.6 degrees in 24 hours. In contrast, coastal Andhra Pradesh and Rayalaseema experienced a rise in temperatures. The forecast predicts shallow fog at isolated places during the morning across north and south coastal AP and Yanam.

articles.title: Zimbabwe leads Africa in submitting updated climate plans to UNFCCC
articles.author: The Chronicle
articles.summary: ZIMBABWE is the only African country that has submitted updated national climate plans to the UNFCCC secretariat. Parties to the Paris Agreement are required to submit updated climate plans every five years. Only 13 countries had met the deadline by Monday, 10 February 2025, according to the African Climate Policy Centre (ACPC).

articles.title: Extreme weather is our new reality. We must accept it and begin planning
articles.author: Gaia Vince
articles.summary: Global average temperatures are already 1.75C above the preindustrial average. January 2025 was the hottest on record and set a record for the highest yearly minimum global surface temperature. Last year's global average was 1.6C above preindustrial. Disasters will be more frequent and more severe in the coming decades. People are dying and having their lives destroyed.

articles.title: Sea erosion at Kulasekarapattinam causes concern as over 100 palm trees fall into sea
articles.author: Online Desk
articles.summary: 100 palm trees along the Kulasekarapattinam coast in Thoothukudi district have fallen into the sea due to severe erosion. Activists have urged the government to take immediate action to protect the remaining trees on the shoreline. The falling trees pose safety risks for devotees of the Mutharamman Temple.

articles.title: La Niña conditions expected to give way come spring: What does it mean?
articles.author: Luke Peteley
articles.summary: Since January, La Niña conditions have prevailed in the Pacific Ocean, which is the cold phase of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation, a recurring climate pattern of fluctuations in sea surface temperatures in the central and eastern tropical Pacific Ocean. ENSO-neutral conditions prevail when water temperatures are near-average, which typically results in average winter conditions across the U.S.

articles.title: OPINION: Fight climate disinformation for your children and the future of Planet Earth
articles.author: Cathy Orlando
articles.summary: Cathy Orlando is a climate activist from Sudbury, Canada. She is concerned about climate change and the spread of climate disinformation. CCL Canada has compiled a booklet on key climate issues, election integrity, and effective communication strategies. They launched an Open Letter urging Elections Canada to investigate Elon Musk and protect election integrity. They are preparing another digital campaign urging opposition parties to delay triggering a federal election until all recommendations from the Foreign Interference Report are enacted. They will join a call with Duff Conacher of Democracy Watch on March 4 at 8 p.m. to discuss urgent actions their parliamentarians must do now to protect Canada.

articles.title: Grade 10 Science Examination Question PNG: PNG Online School
articles.summary: Grade 10 Science Examination questions are designed to assess students' understanding of key scientific concepts and their ability to apply knowledge to real-life situations. Past examination papers, such as the 2015 Grade 10 Science paper in Papua New Guinea, serve as valuable resources for students. Reviewing these questions helps students build confidence and improve their performance in the final examination.

articles.title: MARTINO: Issues arise as snow geese expand range
articles.author: John Martino
articles.summary: Large flocks of snow geese are rarely seen in central Indiana. Some believe their migratory routes are expanding due to their growing numbers and an increase in hunting pressure as they make their way across the United States and Canada. Snow geese hunting guides and outfitters have sprung up all along migration routes.

articles.title: The world's oldest continent that formed 4bn years ago is also the fastest moving
articles.author: Kris Boratyn
articles.summary: Australia is the fastest-moving continent on Earth. It is on the Indo-Australian tectonic plate and drifts northeast at about 2.7 inches per year. Its landscape is the lowest, flattest, and second-driest continent after Antarctica. Its geography has been reshaped over thousands of years due to changing sea levels. Around 18,000 years ago, New Guinea, Tasmania, and mainland Australia were connected.

articles.title: AUB Director Calls for Increased Media Collaboration on Climate Change
articles.author: Macpherson Mukuka
articles.summary: UNDRR Head of Channel and Content, Fanny Legella, says rural communities remain highly vulnerable to climate shocks. AUB Director-General, Gregoire Ndjaka, has called for increased media collaboration to effectively disseminate climate change information.

articles.title: Climate Adaptation Center honors resilience efforts in the community
articles.author: Ian Swaby
articles.summary: The Climate Adaptation Center's Climate Champions Awards were held on February 12 at Michael's on East in Sarasota. Four people were honored for their efforts in climate resilience. This year's honorees were David Kotok, Karen Holbrook, A.G. Lafley and Tracie Troxler.

articles.title: The Role of Science in Debunking Climate Myths
articles.author: B.Sc. Jessica Taylor
articles.summary: Climate myths are misconceptions or misleading ideas that spread faster than the truth. Some people believe that climate change is a natural cycle and not influenced by human activity, while others believe it is a hoax invented for political gain. Science plays a crucial role in distinguishing fact from fiction, providing clarity and insight. Education plays a key role in combating climate myths.

articles.title: Climate change could put your favourite sweet treat at risk
articles.author: Manchester Evening News
articles.summary: "It's a nightmare – and it's all down to climate change," says Mr. Obama. "It is a nightmare and it is all due to the climate change."    "I am worried about the future of the planet."  "

articles.title: Melbourne residents jolted awake by recycling-for-cash container
articles.summary: Melbourne residents have shared their frustrations about being jolted awake for months by a noisy recycling-for-cash container in their backyards for months. They complain about being woken up by the container's loud noise and noise pollution, which they find annoying.

articles.title: Greenland Daily Life
articles.author: 해외주식투자 感 Gam
articles.summary: A piece of ice floating in the water off the shore in Nuuk, Greenland, Friday, Feb. 14, 2025, was found by a woman standing next to the water. She was looking for a place to put it on the shore. She found it.

articles.title: ‘Earth's axis and orbit shape its seasons— other planets have winter and summer too'
articles.author: Srijana Mitra Das
articles.summary: John Chiang is Professor of Geography at the University of California, Berkeley. He uses a combination of theory, observational analyses, data from satellites and meteorological stations and model simulations to understand how climate works and changes. Earth's axis, tilt and orbital eccentricity influence Earth's seasons.

articles.title: Threat of Wexford's coastal erosion grows amid stark warning – ‘We can't protect everywhere'
articles.author: Pádraig Byrne
articles.summary: Almost €2 million in funding was recently allocated towards coastal protection works to preserve access to five homes at Seaview near Kilmore Quay. Not 200 metres away, a farmer is fighting a losing battle with the furious sea, which is steadily making its way towards the family home and a shed full of machinery.

articles.title: Oh look at that – NZ suffering from Heat Stroke – so how's that climate change that isn't happening going?
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: The last 10 days have been the hottest continuous 10 or 11 days on record. Last month was the warmest January on record, with surface – air temperatures 1.75C above preindustrial levels. Almost 600 000 workers couldn't go to work in California in January because of the fires.

articles.title: CEFCU's Athlete of the Week: Cooper Schallenberg
articles.summary: It's 32.32°C outside. It's raining in the south.   Â. Â ÂÂ   yestestatestatostatestagestagetagetatagetagsetag.com.

articles.title: Record January heat suggests La Niña may be losing its ability to keep global warming in check
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: January 2025 was the hottest on record. It was 1.7°C above pre-industrial levels. The record heat highlights how human-driven ocean warming is increasingly overwhelming natural climate patterns, as shown by the recent data.   .

articles.title: Temperatures rising in most parts of Oman: Met
articles.author: Vinod Nair
articles.summary: Temperatures in several governorates of Oman are gradually moving up to the late 20s and above. The world just had its warmest January on record. The record heat occurred despite the emergence of a La Niña event, which normally has a temporary cooling effect.

articles.title: VIDEO: Birdwatchers travel across country in boost for Australia's tourism industry
articles.summary: Birdwatching is pouring billions into Australia's tourism industry as twitchers and nature lovers travel across Australia to tick birds off their list and visit nature reserves and nature reserves.       "Birdwatching" is a billion dollar industry in Australia.

articles.title: Air evacuations underway as ex-Tropical Cyclone Zelia triggers dangerous flooding
articles.author: Elijah
articles.summary: Zelia, a former tropical cyclone, crossed the WA coast east of Port Hedland on Friday. It caused heavy rains and floods in the Pilbara de Wa region. The Degrey river is expected to reach the flood level on Saturday afternoon. At least 63 people have been evacuated from Warralong's remote community. There were 60 calls for help around the area after the cyclone's coup, but one of the most busy iron mineral load ports was saved.

articles.title: Air evacuations underway as ex-tropical cyclone Zelia triggers dangerous flooding
articles.author: RACHEL WARD
articles.summary: Rising flood waters triggered by heavy rainfall in a cyclone will pose a danger in northwestern Australia for days. West Australian Premier Roger Cook urged residents to stay alert. A severe weather warning for heavy rainfall has been issued for the Pilbara, Gascoyne, North Interior and South Interior districts. The DeGrey River at the Great Northern Highway is expected to reach major flood level on Saturday afternoon. 63 people have been evacuated from the remote community of Warralong as floodwaters rise. A record 500mm of rain fell in just three days in parts of Pilbara. 278mm was recorded at Upper North Pole in just 18 hours.

articles.title: Air evacuations as ex-cyclone Zelia triggers flooding
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Rising flood waters triggered by heavy rainfall in a cyclone will pose a danger in northwestern Australia for days. West Australian Premier Roger Cook urged residents to stay alert after record rainfall. A severe weather warning for heavy rainfall has been issued for the Pilbara, Gascoyne, North Interior and South Interior districts. DeGrey River at the Great Northern Highway is expected to reach major flood level on Saturday.

articles.title: Air evacuations as ex-cyclone Zelia triggers flooding
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Rising flood waters triggered by heavy rainfall in a cyclone will pose a danger in northwestern Australia for days. West Australian Premier Roger Cook urged residents to stay alert. The DeGrey River at the Great Northern Highway is expected to reach major flood level on Saturday. A record 500mm of rain fell in just three days in parts of the Pilbara, with 278mm recorded at Upper North Pole in just 18 hours. The mining hub Port Hedland was spared the worst of Zelia's destructive winds.

articles.title: Opinion Express View on Global Climate Risk Index: It's not all gloom and doom
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: There were 9,400 extreme weather events between 1993 and 2022. Floods, heatwaves, and cyclones claimed more than 7,65,000 lives in this period. The economic losses due to these events amounted to more than $4 trillion. India was the sixth worst-affected country in the period.

articles.title: VIDEO: WA Premier Roger Cook gives update on ex-tropical cyclone Zelia
articles.summary: WA Premier Roger Cook has warned of floodwaters in the Pilbara region. He is providing an update on ex-tropical cyclone Zelia, which has caused flooding in the area.    - W.A. Premier's office has no further comment on the matter.

articles.title: Spike Milligan: The 'goon' who loved Australia
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: Spike Milligan visited Australia to visit his brother in Woy Woy, NSW. Bill McAuley took a photo of Milligan during an airport interview in Sydney. Bill is an award-winning photojournalist with a 40-plus-year news career.

articles.title: Warning over 'toxic' beach 'myth' hurting Aussies: 'Always ignored'
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Professor of Chemistry Oliver Jones at RMIT University is trying to dispel the myth that sunscreen is bad for you. He believes it's part of the wider mistrust of chemicals that we see on social media. He is hopeful with good science communication and critical thinking skills, we can push back against harmful misinformation.

articles.title: World's sea-ice falls to record low
articles.summary: Arctic sea-ice is at its smallest extent for the time of year, while Antarctic sea ice is close to a new record low. The Arctic is expected to be essentially free of sea ice at the end of the summer before 2050. The Antarctic sea- ice has been tracking very low since late 2024.

articles.title: March, April temperatures in Sri Lanka expected to be higher than previous years
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Temperatures in Sri Lanka during March and April 2025 may be higher than in previous years, says a meteorologist. Dry weather conditions are the reason for the possibility of higher temperatures, he adds.       in Xinhua's report on Saturday.

articles.title: Expert warns of worsening water crisis in Turkey
articles.author: Duvar
articles.summary: Expert Erol Kesici has said Turkey has lost wetlands equal to two Marmara Seas in 50 years due to climate change. He claims the loss of wetlands is due to the decline of wetlands in Turkey.   for more information visit: http://www.erolkesici.com/

articles.title: Delhi records second-hottest day of the year, mercury at 28.6°C
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Delhi experienced its second warmest day of the year on Sunday. The temperature reached 28.6°C, which is four degrees above the usual average. The hottest day on record was February 11, when the temperature reached 29.7°C.

articles.title: Where is PH's heat action plan?
articles.author: The Philadelphia Inquirer
articles.summary: People living in the Philippines are enjoying pleasant weather due to the lingering effects of La Niña, but it should not be taken for granted as La Niñas are still lingering in the area, which is bad for people living there. It should be treated as normal.

articles.title: How climate change is reshaping India's tribal landscape
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: How climate change is reshaping Indias tribal landscape and changing the tribal landscape.   Â. Â   in this article we look at the impact of climate change on India's tribal landscape, and how it's reshaping the society as a whole.

articles.title: AI is the future of tech, but its effects on the climate could change everything
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Microsoft's and Google's emissions have increased by 30 percent since 2020 and 50 percent since 2000 respectively. Tech is investing in artificial intelligence and energy-hungry data centers, which are responsible for increasing climate emissions in the last few years, especially in the tech industry.

articles.title: Earth is already shooting through the 1.5°C global warming limit, two major studies show
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Earth is crossing the threshold of 1.5°C of global warming, according to two major global studies. Under the landmark 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change, humanity is seeking to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and keep the Earth warmer.   .   i

articles.title: The Sands of Time, St. Augustine and Louis Armstrong
articles.author: The Crescent News
articles.summary: The hourglass has flipped over 3,800 times since we were there. The sand has warmed our feet and cooled them by the ocean waves, so we took off our shoes to play in the sand and the hourglass, which has flipped more than 3,000 times in that time.

articles.title: ‘Earth's axis and orbit shape its seasons— other planets have winter and summer too'
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: John Chiang is Professor of Geography at the University of California, Berkeley. He is interested in how Earth's global climate works and how it brings about changes from seasonal to permanent. He explains to Srijana Mitra Das how frost changes to warmth on Earth.

articles.title: India among 10 countries most affected by extreme weather events during 30 years between 1992 ...
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: Countries in the Global South have been affected most by extreme weather events in the last 30 years, according to The Climate Risk Index 2025 published by Germanwatch. In some cases such as Dominica, losses incurred by a single extreme weather event can be many times higher than entire gross.

articles.title: Climate, clean energy bills deserve support
articles.author: Richmond Times Dispatch
articles.summary: There are plenty of signs that the climate crisis is getting worse, but scientists say we haven't seen anything yet. There are apocalyptic wildfires, hurricanes, droughts and floods galore, but still, scientists say, nothing's been done about it yet.

articles.title: Extreme weather is our new reality. We must accept it and begin planning
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The post-climate change era has arrived. Now we need honesty and action from our leaders, as shown by the recent climate change-related catastrophes, such as wildfires, floods, droughts and record-breaking temperatures, and we need to take action.

articles.title: Want to make sure you don't swelter in your next home? Check these 12 features ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: After the warmest spring on record, Australia is baking through another scorching summer. Hot, dry, windy weather again swept across the country this week. It was the second-warmest January on record in Australia, after the first one in January.

articles.title: In Scotland, ‘green lairds' are buying vast estates for carbon credits
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Locals fear the 'green rush' will result in even more extreme concentration of land ownership in a warming world as a result of the climate change.      .   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Climate adaptation: Ensuring resilience in agriculture (CGIAR System Organization - Consortium of International Agricultural Research Centers)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: There are hundreds of millions of smallholder farmers in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia who are facing the challenges of climate change. Many of them were already struggling, and now the surge of extreme weather the world has experienced over the past few years is damaging and destroying their means of survival.

articles.title: Bowling Green State University students to study volcanoes in Antarctica this semester
articles.author: Newark Advocate
articles.summary: Satellite imagery tracks the path of the world's largest iceberg since it broke free in Antarctica's Weddell Sea in early November 2023. Two Bowling Green State University students and their professor will spend two months in the area to do fieldwork in an area that most people don't get to explore.

articles.title: Why Kerala warmed up like never before in a century in 2024?
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record globally and India's warmest on record. Global temperatures crossed 1.55 degrees Celsius, surpassing the Paris Agreement's 1.5-degree threshold. In India, 10 out of the 15 warmest years were observed in the recent fifteen years (2010-2024). The past decade was also the warmest decade on record, with the decadal averaged annual mean temperature anomaly of 0.31 degrees Celsius. Rising temperatures and changing monsoon patterns pose a threat to Kerala's agrarian economy.
